page.title: Senufo female ancestor figure (Indianapolis Museum of Art)

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Female ancestor figure by Senufo people.jpg | painting_alignment = | image_size = 150px | title = Female ancestor figure | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = | year = 1900-1940 | type = [[Wood carving]] | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 41.675 | width_imperial = 8 | length_imperial = 3.75 | diameter__metric = | diameter_imperial = | imperial_unit = in | metric_unit = cm | city = [[Indianapolis]] | museum = [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] | coordinates = | owner = }}
This wooden female ancestor figure by an unknown [[Senufo people|Senufo]] artisan is part of the [[Africa]]n collection of the [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]], which is in [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]]. Carved in the first half of the 20th century, it displays the artist's skill with form and respect for the powerful female half of the primordial couple.<ref name=lee>{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Ellen Wardwell|last2=Robinson|first2=Anne|title=Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection|publisher=[[Indianapolis Museum of Art]]|location=Indianapolis|year=2005|isbn=0936260777}}</ref>
==Description== [[Romare Bearden]] once declared of this statue that "It’s the rhythms . . . that are so beautiful: the head and the two breasts, the length of the arms coming down to her waist." The figure is beautifully balanced and proportioned, with an arched back leading down from her delicate head to the weighty fists on her hips. This combination of strength and grace is fitting for the Mother Ancestor of the Senufo. She is heavily ornamented, with a helmetlike hairstyle, armlets, [[lip plug]], and body markings across her torso, breasts, and temples. She has sharply conical breasts to signify her ideal womanhood and long arms to show that she is a caretaker.<ref name=lee/>
==Historical information== As half of the ancestral couple of the Senufo people, this statue would have been kept with her mate in a shrine. The pair would only be taken out for special occasions such as funeral processions, when the newly dead were initiated into the spirit world. During these processions, the statue would be alternately swung from side to side and struck against the ground to serve as percussion.<ref name=ima/>
===Acquisition=== This work entered the IMA's collection in 1999 thanks to the Mr. and Mrs. Richard Crane Fund, the Anonymous Art Fund, the Mary V. Black Art Endowment Fund, the Lucille Stewart Endowed Art Fund, the Mrs. Pierre F. Goodrich Endowed Art Fund, and the General Endowed Art Fund. It now has the accession number 1999.31 and is on display in the Eiteljorg Suite of African and Oceanic Art.<ref name=ima>{{cite web|title=female ancestor figure|url=http://www.imamuseum.org/collections/artwork/female-ancestor-figure|publisher=[[Indianapolis Museum of Art]]|accessdate=6 June 2013}}</ref> It was heralded as a highlight of the collection when the gallery first opened in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eiteljorg Gallery of African Art Opens Tomorrow|url=http://www.absolutearts.com/artsnews/2000/08/18/27343.html|publisher=Indepth Art News|accessdate=6 June 2013|date=19 Aug 2000}}</ref>
==Condition== The figure's lower legs, feet, and a probable circular wooden base have eroded away due to a combination of water and insect damage, which also left the legs discolored. Its surface has been darkened by extensive handling and the tropical conditions of [[Ivory Coast]].<ref name=ima/>
==See also== * [[Mother goddess]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.imamuseum.org/collections/artwork/female-ancestor-figure IMA page].
{{IMAart}}

'''Shanghai-style papercutting''' is a variety of [[papercutting]] practiced in south China, and in particular in [[Shanghai]].
The making of papercuts is a popular [[folk art]] in China. In the hands of an artisan, and with the help of a knife or a pair of scissors, a piece of paper can be turned into any of a wide variety of patterns – landscapes, flowers, birds, animals and human figures. These simple works of art may be displayed in wall frames or pressed under glass and displayed to decorate a room.
Traditional North Chinese papercut works are mostly patterns of auspicious symbols, patterns, with strong traditional features. While Shanghai-style papercutting, based on applied arts such as [[Chuanghua]] (papercut for window decoration, Chinese: 窗花), or embroidery, does not adhere to the traditional symbols. Its subjects and designs are relatively more simple and modern. More uniquely, Shanghai-style papercuts, regardless of their size and complexity, are all cut at one time and the cut flowers, grasses and animals, are all attached together.
Different from the traditional red papercut, the most obvious feature of Shanghai-style papercut is its colors and patterns. Waste paper such as flyer paper, newspapers, envelopes are all used as the materials for creating these works. Shanghai-style artists make use of the original colors of the paper to conceive the design, the colors and patterns of their works.<ref>[http://www.godpp.gov.cn/wmzh/2008-02/01/content_12375150.htm 海派剪纸艺术传承父子( Transmitters of Shanghai-style papercutting )], 解放日报, 1 February 2008</ref>
[[Shanghai culture and arts]] is an important part of [[Chinese arts and craft]]. It has a tradition of excellence, substantial accumulation, excellent artists and craftsmen, a brilliant memory. Let us review it: Shanghai since its inception in 1843, Started from the closed Wuyue regional smallholder city to become a coastal modern cities, called "The Jianghai Tongjin, southeast of the city". It is in such an open and emerging cities, breeding and the formation of The Shanghai Arts and Crafts, the Beijing School of Arts and Crafts Arts and Crafts of Guangdong faction formed with distinct regional characteristics.<ref>[http://www.artjcb.com/gmsc/gymslt/images/96.pdf 对申博成功后海派工艺美术的思考与预测], 上海电台王琪森</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=February 2018}} {{advert|date=February 2018}} {{Orphan|date=February 2018}} }} {{Infobox magazine | italic title = Smith Journal | title = Smith Journal | image_file = | image_caption = Volume 9 | editor = Chris Harrigan | previous_editor = Nadia Saccardo | category = Men, Culture, Art, Design, Photography, Style, Fashion, | frequency = Quarterly | publisher = [[Morrison Media]] | total_circulation = 32,000<ref>[http://www.smithjournal.com.au/media-kit]</ref> | founded = 2011 | country = Australia | based = Melbourne | language = English | website = {{URL|smithjournal.com.au}} }}
'''''Smith Journal''''' is a quarterly Australian magazine based in Melbourne, and founded in 2011. The publication focuses on history, photography, art, and design, but also features articles on architecture, fashion, science, DIY, adventure, and literature. ''Smith Journal'' is published by Frankie Press,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.frankiepress.com.au/|title=frankie press // frankie magazine // smith journal // Slow|website=www.frankiepress.com.au|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref> creators of popular Australian magazine '''''[[Frankie (magazine)|frankie]]'''.'' The magazine is lauded for sharing the same "inquisitive nature, intelligent copy and compelling stories"<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.pedestrian.tv/news/meet-frankies-mens-spinoff-smith-journal/|title=Meet Frankie's Men's Spinoff "Smith Journal" – Pedestrian TV|date=9 August 2011|work=Pedestrian TV|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US}}</ref> as ''frankie''.
== History and profile == ''Smith Journal'' was founded by frankie press editors-at-large Rick Bannister and Louise Bannister as a men’s magazine in the same vein as ''frankie.'' It was designed to attract readers interested in “real people doing real things, guys that are making stuff, creative thinkers, adventurers, whatever.”<ref name=":1" />
The magazine was initially planned to be published on a bi-annual schedule,<ref name="adnews.com.au">{{Cite news|url=http://www.adnews.com.au/adnews/frankie-launches-smith-journal-in-a-leap-of-faith|title=Frankie launches Smith Journal in a leap of faith – AdNews|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en}}</ref> but adopted a quarterly publishing schedule following its positive reception.
Similar to ''frankie,'' the magazine is printed on premium matte paper stock, and marketed as a "bespoke"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://theconversation.com/why-the-saturday-papers-design-breeds-disappointment-24198|title=Why The Saturday Paper's design breeds disappointment|last=Sadokierski|first=Zoe|work=The Conversation|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en}}</ref> title suitable as both a casual read and coffee table magazine.
''Smith Journal'' is owned and published by niche publisher Morrison Media, parent owners of Frankie Press who also publish ''frankie'' magazine.<ref name=":0" /> Morrison Media moved production of its titles to [[Melbourne]] in February 2014 when it closed its [[Queensland]] based offices.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mumbrella.com.au/frankie-press-co-founders-depart-204965|title=Frankie Press co-founders depart as Morrison Media moves sales hub to Melbourne – Mumbrella|date=7 February 2014|work=Mumbrella|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US}}</ref> Later that year, Morrison Media was acquired by Pacific Star Network in November 2014 for $10m AUD.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mumbrella.com.au/frankie-publisher-morrison-media-bought-10m-deal-262164|title=Frankie publisher Morrison Media bought out in $10m deal – Mumbrella|date=12 November 2014|work=Mumbrella|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
''Smith Journal's'' name is derived from the titles used for professional [[Writer|wordsmiths]] or [[blacksmith]]s; traditional artisans and craftsmen that embody the down-to-earth quality the magazine attempts to emulate.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.scout.com.au/Blog/Smith-Journal---a-smart-new-publication-from-Frankie-Magazine|title=Smith Journal: a smart new publication from Frankie Magazine|work=Scout|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref><ref name=":1" />
== Content == The magazine's somewhat niche content and minimalistic approach to topics is a direct response to the salacious "lad mags" of the magazine industry such as ''[[FHM]]'' and ''[[Zoo Weekly]].'' At the time of ''Smith Journal's'' launch, the men's magazine market largely consisted of [[Popular culture|populist]] focused titles with a very broad target audience such as ''[[Men's Health]]'', or hobby-specific titles dedicated to a singular topic. Instead of attempting to engage as many readers as possible through glossy pages filled with current events topics, the editors of ''Smith Journal'' felt that there was a "gap in the market for guys who felt that their magazines hadn't grown or changed with them."<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/from-zoo-to-smith-journal-are-men-finally-choosing-brains-over-boobs-20140619-zsf9r.html|title=From Zoo to Smith Journal: Are men finally choosing brains over boobs?|last=Watson|first=Meg|date=28 June 2014|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2018-01-30|language=en-US}}</ref> According to the founding editor Nadia Saccardo, the magazine was not created with an emphasis on a specific gender, but was instead focused on "unexpected, accessible storytelling coupled with great photography and illustration."<ref name=":3" />
Many of the articles focus on topics and individuals related to history, photography, art and design. Volume 25 profiles photographer Daniel George, whose portfolio consists of household items used for [[target practice]]; an article discussing the cultural re-evaluation of [[Glam metal|1980s hair metal]] music; and an interview with former [[NASA]] scientist Robert Lang who now designs [[origami]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/this-volume|title=Volume 25|date=30 January 2018|access-date=2018-01-30|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180130074538/http://www.smithjournal.com.au/this-volume|archivedate=30 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Previous issues have also included interviews with American musician [[Henry Rollins]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/past-volumes/2686-smith-journal-volume-20|title=Volume 20|website=www.smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref> and professional safe-cracker [[Jeff Sitar]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/past-volumes/2489-smith-journal-volume-17|title=Volume Seventeen|website=www.smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref> an historical article on Soviet rocket architect [[Galina Balashova]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/past-volumes/2701-volume-nineteen|title=Volume Nineteen|website=www.smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref> and Brazil's illegal [[hot air balloon]] subculture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/past-volumes/2385-volume-sixteen|title=Volume Sixteen|website=www.smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref>
The stylistic design of the magazine makes use of a large amount of white space and very [[Minimalism (disambiguation)|minimalistic]] photographs and illustrations with text pairings. Many articles are presented on a stark white background, some without a headline or photo to accompany it. A number of photographs are presented on a [[two-page spread]]. All of the photographs adhere to a similar [[Image editing|editing]] style which includes faded blacks to complement the matte paper they are printed on.
Issues will often include tear-out posters of illustrations or diagrams. For example, Volume 25 features an illustrated diagram of the [[Lunar calendar|2018 lunar calendar]], and Volume 18 included a twenty-sided [[icosahedron]] globe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/past-volumes/2468-smith-journal-volume-18|title=Volume Eighteen|website=www.smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref>
These content and design choices are intentionally similar in style to ''[[Frankie (magazine)|frankie]],'' another Frankie Press publication. Editor-at-Large Louise Bannister stated that "they're from the same family – lots of white space…but the treatment of pictures and text is a little different."<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.broadsheet.com.au/melbourne/art-and-design/article/frankies-mens-spin-smith-journal-hits-stands|title=Frankie's Men's Spin-Off, Smith Journal, Hits The Stands|work=Broadsheet|access-date=2018-01-30|language=en}}</ref> During its initial creation, ''Smith Journal'' was designed by ''frankie'' magazine's Creative Director, Lara Burke, with additional input from ''frankie's'' editor, Jo Walker and Senior Contributor, Benjamin Walker.<ref name=":1" /> However, Bannister was quick to point out that despite the similarities, "Smith is its own thing."<ref name=":4" />
== Launch == The first issue of ''Smith Journal'' was published in Australia on 5 September 2011. Frankie Press circulated 20,000 copies<ref name="adnews.com.au"/> of the first issue which contained 140 pages.<ref name=":2" />
When the magazine first launched in September 2011, it was during a period when a significantly large number of men's magazines were declining in sales and reader numbers. For example, ''FHM'' had posted a 20 percent drop from 2010 to 2011 to reach a record low of 40,000 circulated copies in Australia, and ''Zoo Weekly'' had dropped 18 percent to 83,000 circulated copies.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/size-doesnt-matter-in-a-shrinking-market-mens-magazines-try-new-models-to-stay-on-top-20110813-1is6i.html|title=Size doesn't matter. In a shrinking market, men's magazines try new models to stay on top|last=Lallo|first=Michael|date=14 August 2011|work=The Age|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US}}</ref> Other men's titles such as ''Alpha, Sport & Style,'' and ''Ralph'' all folded in the same span of time.<ref name=":5" />'' ''
In response to the decision to launch a new men's magazine when a large number of others were closing, then editorial director Louise Bannister suggested ''Smith Journal'' was not intended to appeal to a mass audience, but instead to a smaller group of people interested in "something they can't get on the internet."<ref name=":5" />
== Readership == ''Smith Journal's'' readers are predominantly male, however, the magazine also holds a fairly sizable female reader base (70% male, 30% female).<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/media-kit|title=Media Kit|work=smithjournal.com.au|access-date=2018-01-30|language=en-GB}}</ref> The magazine's media kit states that 58% of its readers are between 25–44 years old, and that 70% are university educated or are currently studying.<ref name=":6" />
Former editor Nadia Saccardo described the magazine's reader as curious and open-minded and that the content was designed to attract readers "who feel like they have been ignored, or would not traditionally pick up magazines."<ref name=":3" /> Editor-at-Large Rick Bannister elaborated on this statement by describing the magazine's average reader as someone who is creative and interested in reviving old traditions such as "brewing, or making furniture, or restoring bikes."<ref name=":1" />
Besides the quarterly issue, the magazine also features an online presence through its website ''smithjournal.com.au.''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://smithjournal.com.au/|title=Australian Magazine in Blog Form {{!}} Smith Journal|website=smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref> The website includes original articles and weekly blog posts not found in the magazine that cover a wider range of subjects and topics than the magazine usually focuses on. The website receives an average number of 19,900 unique visitors (six-month average), and 41,150+ average page views per month (media kit). ''Smith Journal'' also has an online shop where visitors can purchase individual copies (for domestic or international shipping), issues of the digital magazine, as well as past copies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.frankiepress.com.au/shop/|title=buy frankie magazine & Smith Journal magazine {{!}} frankie press|website=www.frankiepress.com.au|language=en|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref>
== Staff == * '''Editor''' Chris Harrigan, previously Nadia Saccardo * '''Assistant Editor''' Taz Liffman * '''Designer''' Anjana Jain * '''Digital Director''' Suzi Taylor * '''Writers''' [[Mel Campbell]], Kane Daniel, Carl Dansk, [[The Bedroom Philosopher|Justin Heazlewood]], Koren Helbig, Christopher Hollow, Bryce Howorth, Marina Kamenev, Leta Keens, Brodie Lancaster, Ben McLeay, Stephin Merritt, Andrew Mueller, Max Olijnyk, Kieran Pender, Patrick Pittman, Justin Quirk, Luke Ryan, James Shackell, Rory Taggart, Alex Warren * '''Photographers''' Alice Aedy, Nicolas Blandin, Jeremy Bowtell, Jean-Marc Caimi, Carlos Chavarria, Chris Crerar, Elsie El-asmar, Daniel George, Mick Hutson, Charlie Kinross, Misha Petrov * '''Illustrators''' Indigo O'Rourke, Timothy Rodgers, George Wylesol * '''Notable contributors''': [[Dave Eggers]], [[Elizabeth Gilbert]], [[Tim Winton]]
== Contributors == ''Smith Journal'' has had a number of notable writers contribute to the magazine's content. [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning writer and editor [[Dave Eggers]], author of popular novels ''[[A Hologram for the King]]'' and ''[[The Circle (Eggers novel)|The Circle]],'' contributed a personal narrative in the magazine's second issue.<ref name=":3" /> [[Elizabeth Gilbert]], author of ''[[Eat, Pray, Love]]'', has contributed an opinion piece on science and adventure.<ref name=":3" /> Australian writer [[Tim Winton]] had an article titled "10 Things I Believe" also published by the magazine.<ref name=":3" />
== References == <references />
== External links == * [http://www.smithjournal.com.au Official Smith Journal website] * [http://www.pacificstarnetwork.com.au/ Pacific Star Network website]

Johannes von Nepomuk in Divina | other_language_2 = Bulgarian | other_title_2 = Статуя на св. Ян Непомуцки в Дивина | artist = Unknown | year = 1796 | completion_date = 2017 | catalogue = | type = Sculpture | movement = Late [[baroque]] | subject = Saint [[John of Nepomuk]] | height_metric = 150 | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | designation = | condition =Renovation: 1822, 1995, 2017 | museum = | city = [[Divina]], Slovakia | coordinates = | owner = Parish of Divina, [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Žilina]] | accession = | module = | website = | italic title = no | material = Sandstone | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} The statue of [[John of Nepomuk|St. John of Nepomuk]] in [[Divina]] is the National Cultural Monument of [[Slovakia]]. Divina is a [[village]] and [[municipality]] in [[Žilina District]] in the [[Žilina Region]] of northern Slovakia. In [[History|historical records]] the [[village]] was first mentioned in 1325. The Statue of St. John of Nepomuk is registered in the Central List of the Slovak Memorial Fund under the number 1334/2.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pamiatky.sk/po/po/Details?id=9364|title=Pamiatkový objekt - podrobnosti|website=www.pamiatky.sk|language=sk|access-date=2017-06-19|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170806221237/http://www.pamiatky.sk/po/po/Details?id=9364|archivedate=2017-08-06|df=}} It is a sandstone sculpture from 1796 standing on a stone base. The statue has a good artistic elaboration of the saint’s face and drapery. The saint does not have a traditional [[biretta]] on his head. The statue is a remembrance of the last male descendant of the [[Aristocratic family|aristocratic]] Szunyogh family – John Nepomuk Szunyogh, who is credited with the construction of the Divina church and rectory. In Slovakia, there are only few preserved architectural and artistic monuments that belonged to the count branch of the Szunyog family of [[Budatín Castle|Budatín]]. In 1588, the branch was promoted to [[baron]]s, later [[count]]s. The last male descendant was John Nepomuk Szunyogh, who died in 1798, leaving only one daughter Josephine. St. John of Nepomuk was his personal patron, to whom he had a special reverence. [[Image:Okres zilina.png|thumb|right|300px|Location of [[Žilina District]] in the [[Zilina Region]]]] == St. John of Nepomuk == St. John of Nepomuk, Czech saint, died as a [[martyr]]. His tortured body was bound and thrown in the [[Vltava]] river. St. John of Nepomuk is one of the most frequently illustrated saints in the territory of the former [[Habsburg Monarchy|Habsburg monarchy]] and there are monuments (mostly statues) of him in almost every village in Slovak and [[Czech Republic|Czechia]]. His statues and other monuments are all over the world. The fact that we can find St. John of Nepomuk also in less expected locations only confirms his universal respect. St. John is the patron of confessors, priests, sailors, rafters, millers and protector from drowning or tongue diseases. He is co-patron of the Czech Republic and [[Bavaria]].{{Cite journal|date=2017-07-18|title=John of Nepomuk|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=John_of_Nepomuk&oldid=791145027|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}} Many churches and chapels have been consecrated to him in Central and Western Europe. St. John of Nepomuk churches and chapels can be found in [[Germany]], Czechia, [[Poland]], [[Italy]], Slovakia, [[Slovenia]], [[Austria]], [[Serbia]], [[Lithuania]] and [[Hungary]]. His is also worshipped in [[Spain]]. Since 16 May 1758, St. John of Nepomuk has been the patron saint of the Spanish Marine Forces (''Infantería de Marina'').{{Cite web|url=http://www.armada.mde.es/ArmadaPortal/page/Portal/Armadaespannola/conocenos_organizacion/prefLang_es/03_Flota--04_Flota-Fuerza-Infanteria-Marina--03_patronazgo-cuerpo-infanteria-marina_es|title=Patronazgo del Cuerpo de Infantería de Marina|last=Fuerza de Infantería de Marina|first=|date=|website=www.armada.mde.es|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160530050704/http://www.armada.mde.es/ArmadaPortal/page/Portal/ArmadaEspannola/conocenos_organizacion/prefLang_es/03_Flota--04_Flota-Fuerza-Infanteria-Marina--03_patronazgo-cuerpo-infanteria-marina_es|archive-date=2016-05-30|dead-url=no|access-date=|df=}} Outside [[Europe]], there churches and chapels consecrated to him especially in [[Costa Rica]], [[Colombia]], [[Paraguay]], [[Argentina]], [[Philippines]] and the [[United States|USA]]. Also names of many municipalities in [[Latin America]] were given in respect of him.{{Cite journal|date=2017-04-22|title=San Juan Nepomuceno, Bolívar|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=San_Juan_Nepomuceno,_Bol%C3%ADvar&oldid=776621206|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sanjuannepomuceno-bolivar.gov.co/index.shtml#8|title=Sitio web del municipio San Juan Nepomuceno en Bolívar|last=http://www.iprc.org.co|first=Equipo de Internet para la Rendición de Cuentas -|website=www.sanjuannepomuceno-bolivar.gov.co|language=es|access-date=2017-07-18}}{{Cite journal|date=2017-05-24|title=San Juan Nepomuceno (Paraguay)|url=https://es.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=San_Juan_Nepomuceno_(Paraguay)&oldid=99355169|journal=Wikipedia, la enciclopedia libre|language=es}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.paraguay.cz/mesto-san-juan-nepomuceno/|title=Město San Juan Nepomuceno|website=www.paraguay.cz|access-date=2017-07-18|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150522003046/http://www.paraguay.cz/mesto-san-juan-nepomuceno/|archivedate=2015-05-22|df=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ngw.nl/heraldrywiki/index.php?title=San_Juan_Nepomuceno_(Paraguay)|title=San Juan Nepomuceno (Paraguay) - Heraldry of the World|website=www.ngw.nl|language=en|access-date=2017-07-18|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170901041126/http://www.ngw.nl/heraldrywiki/index.php?title=San_Juan_Nepomuceno_%28Paraguay%29|archivedate=2017-09-01|df=}} == History == Interesting information about the statue was found in the recently discovered [[Canonical visitation]] of Divina from 1828: ''"On the territory of the parish, there is also on stone statue of St. John Nepomuk, which used to be located at the entrance to the Divina village near the stream along the road in 1796. It was built by the count John Szunyogh. After the fatal massive [[flood]] in 1822 that wrecked the entire village from the ground, the statue was swept away. It was found head-less. Later, thanks to the willingness of the count Stephen Csáky, the current patron of the church, it was repaired and placed in front of the rectory on the brick column."''{{Cite book|title=Canonica visitatio, Nagy Divina|last=Vurum|first=Joseph|publisher=The Diocese of Nitra, manuscript|year=1828|isbn=|location=Nitra|pages=14|language=Latin}} === Another characteristic === * '''Century''': 18th * '''Founder:''' Count John Nepomuk Szunyogh (1796) * '''Innovator:''' Count Stephen Csáky (after 1822) == International project of restoration == The project of restoration of St. John of Nepomuk statue was initiated by architect [[Marek Sobola]] and was started in 2016, was completed in June 2017. Partners, who were addressed to cooperate have either some connection to St. John of Nepomuk or to Slovakia. === Auspices === * {{flag|Germany}} : The project was carried out under auspices of the [[Diplomatic mission|Embassy]] of the Federal Republic of Germany in Slovakia.{{Cite web|url=https://www.zilinskyvecernik.sk/clanok/v-divine-zachranili-sochu-s-neobycajnym-pribehom/5977/|title=V Divine zachránili sochu s neobyčajným príbehom {{!}} Žilinský večerník|website=www.zilinskyvecernik.sk|access-date=2017-06-19|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170806222317/https://www.zilinskyvecernik.sk/clanok/v-divine-zachranili-sochu-s-neobycajnym-pribehom/5977/|archivedate=2017-08-06|df=}} === Project patrons === * {{flag|Cambodia}} : His Majesty [[Norodom Sihamoni]], the king of [[Cambodia]] * {{flag|Bulgaria}} : His Majesty [[Simeon Saxe-Coburg-Gotha|Simeon II.]], the last tsar of [[Bulgaria]] === Project donors === * {{flag|Bavaria}} : His Royal Highness [[Franz, Duke of Bavaria]] * {{flag|Vatican}} : The [[Order of the Holy Sepulchre|Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem]] (''Ordo Equestris Sancti Sepulcri Hierosolymitani'' – ''OESSH'').{{cn|date=September 2018}} Emeritus [[Pope Benedict XVI]] gave his support to the restoration of the statue of St. John of Nepomuk. * {{flag|Czech Republic}} : The [[Knights of the Cross with the Red Star]], the only Catholic knight order or Czech origin (''Ordo militaris Crucigerorum cum rubea stella in pede pontis Pragensis'' – ''O.Cr''), Metropolitan Chapter House of [[St. Vitus Cathedral|St. Vitus]] in Prague, which is the owner of the saint’s grave and the city of [[Nepomuk]] – the birthplace of St. John of Nepomuk. * {{flag|Slovakia}} : [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Žilina|Diocese of Žilina]], municipalities of Divina, [[Divinka]] and [[Svederník]].{{Cite journal|last=TK KBS|first=|date=June 11, 2017|title=Požehnali obnovenú sochu sv. overall view === Blessing ceremony === The statue was uncovered on its new stand on Friday 2 June 2017 by Joachim Bleicker, the Ambassador of the Federal Republic of Germany in Slovakia together with Emil Molko, Mayor of Divina and Marek Sobola, author of the project. Subsequently, it was blessed by Mons. [[Tomáš Galis]], [[Bishop in the Catholic Church|Bishop]] of Žilina. It happened more than 190 years since it was restored after being damaged by a flood. Besides the Bishop, Ambassador of Germany and the Head of the Bishop Office, the ceremony was attended also by invited partners. The uncovering and blessing of the statue were followed by a vernissage presenting all partners of the monument restoration on panels.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tkkbs.sk/view.php?cisloclanku=20170605024|title=Biskup Galis požehnal obnovenú sochu sv. {{BLP unsourced|date=September 2016}} [[Image:Steven Shaviro 05A.jpg|thumb|Steven Shaviro (2007)]] '''Steven Shaviro''' ({{IPAc-en|ʃ|ə|ˈ|v|ɪr|oʊ}}; born April 3, 1954) is an American academic, [[philosopher]] and [[cultural critic]] whose areas of interest include [[film theory]], [[time]], [[science fiction]], [[panpsychism]], [[capitalism]], [[affect (psychology)|affect]] and [[subjectivity]]. He earned a PhD from Yale in 1981.
==Work== His most widely read book is ''Doom Patrols'', a "theoretical fiction" that outlines the state of [[postmodernism]] during the early 1990s, using poetic language, personal anecdotes, and creative prose. He has also written extensively about [[music videos]] as an artform.
Additionally, Shaviro has written a book about film theory, ''The Cinematic Body'', which examines the dominance of [[Jacques Lacan|Lacanian]] [[Trope (literature)|trope]]s in contemporary academic film theory. According to Shaviro, the use of [[psychoanalysis]] has mirrored the actions of a [[cult]], with its own religious texts (essays by [[Sigmund Freud|Freud]] and Lacan).
Shaviro's book ''Connected, Or, What It Means to Live in the Network Society'', appeared in 2003. A later book, ''Without Criteria: Kant, Whitehead, Deleuze, and Aesthetics'' was published in May 2009.

{{short description|a composition by Thiuvalluvar about life, love and morals/ethics}} {{redirect|Kural|other uses|Kural (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox book | italic title = | name = Tirukkural
{{lang|ta|திருக்குறள்}} | image = திருக்குறள் தெளிவு.pdf | image_size = | alt = | caption = A typical published original Tamil version of the book | author = [[Valluvar]] | audio_read_by = | title_orig = Muppāl | orig_lang_code = | title_working = Kural | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[India]] | language = [[Old Tamil language|Old Tamil]] | series = [[Patiṉeṇkīḻkaṇakku]] | release_number = | subject = [[Secular ethics]] | genre = [[Poetry]] | set_in = | published = | publisher = | publisher2 = | pub_date = 1812 (first known printed edition) | english_pub_date =1840 | media_type = | pages = | awards = | isbn = | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }} {{Sangam literature}} {{wikisourcelang|ta|திருக்குறள்|Tirukkural}} The '''Tirukkural''' ({{lang-ta|திருக்குறள்}}, literally ''Sacred Verses''), or shortly '''the Kural''', is a classic [[Tamil language|Tamil]] text consisting of 1,330 couplets or [[Kural (poetic form)|Kural]]s, dealing with the everyday virtues of an individual.{{sfn|C. Blackburn, 2000|pp=449–482}}{{sfn|Pillai, 1994|p=}} It is one of the two oldest works now extant in [[Tamil Literature]] in their entirety, the other being the [[Tolkappiyam]].{{sfn|Manavalan, 2009|p=24}} Considered one of the greatest works ever written on ethics and morality, chiefly [[secular ethics]], it is known for its universality and non-denominational nature.{{sfn|Lal, 1992|pp=4333–4334}} It was authored by [[Thiruvalluvar|Valluvar]], also known in full as Thiruvalluvar. The text has been dated variously from 300 BCE to 7th century CE. The traditional accounts describe it as the last work of the third [[Sangam literature|Sangam]], but linguistic analysis suggests a later date of 450 to 500 CE.{{sfn|Zvelebil, 1975|p=124}} Traditionally praised as "the Universal Veda" and "the Universal Code of Conduct,"{{sfn|Manavalan, 2009|p=22}}{{sfn|Zvelebil, 1973|pp=155–156}} the Kural emphasizes on the vital principles of [[non-violence]], [[moral vegetarianism]] or [[veganism]],{{Ref label|A|a|none}} human brotherhood, absence of desires, path of righteousness and truth, and so forth, besides covering a wide range of subjects such as moral codes of rulers, friendship, agriculture, knowledge and wisdom, sobriety, love, and domestic life.{{sfn|Lal, 1992|pp=4333–4334}} The work is commonly quoted in vegetarian conferences, both in [[India]] and abroad.{{sfn|Sanjeevi, 1973|pp=10–16}} Considered as chef d'oeuvre of both Indian and world literature,{{sfn|Pyatigorsky, n.d.|p=515}} the Kural is one of the most important works in the [[Tamil language]] and is often called "the masterpiece of Tamil Literature."{{sfn|Manavalan, 2009|p=24}} This is reflected in some of the other names by which the text is given by, such as the Work of Three Books, Modern Veda, Divine Work, Faultless Word, and Tamil Veda.{{sfn|Manavalan, 2009|p=22}}{{sfn|Cutler, 1992|pp=}} The Kural has influenced several scholars across the ethical, social, political, economical, religious, philosophical, and spiritual spheres.{{sfn|Velusamy and Faraday, 2017|pp=7–13}}{{sfn|Sundaramurthi, 2000|p=624}} Authors influenced by the Kural include [[Ilango Adigal]], [[Kambar (poet)|Kambar]], [[Leo Tolstoy]], [[Mahatma Gandhi]], [[Albert Schweitzer]], [[Constantius Joseph Beschi]], [[Karl Graul]], [[George Uglow Pope]], [[Alexander Piatigorsky]], and [[Yu Hsi]], many of whom have translated the work into their languages. Translated into at least 40 languages as of 2014, the Kural is one of the [[List of literary works by number of translations|most widely translated works]] in the world.{{sfn|Ashraf, n.d.}} Because the life, culture and ethics of the [[Tamil people|Tamils]] are considered to be solely defined in terms of the values set by the Kural, the government and the people of [[Tamil Nadu]] alike uphold the text with utmost reverence.{{sfn|Zvelebil, 1973|pp=156-171}} Along with the [[Gita]], the Kural is a prime candidate nominated to be the national book of India, for which a declaration was passed at the [[Tamil Nadu Assembly]] in 2006.{{sfn|Velusamy and Faraday, 2017|pp=63–80}} ==Etymology== {{main|Glossary of names for the Tirukkural}} The term ''Tirukkural'' is a compound word made of two individual terms, ''tiru'' and ''kural''. ''Tiru'' is an honorific Tamil term that corresponds to the universally Indian, Sanskrit term ''sri'' meaning "holy, sacred, excellent, honorable, and beautiful."{{sfn|Sundaram, 1990|pp=7–16}} The term ''tiru'' has as many as 19 different meanings.{{sfn|Nedunchezhiyan, 1991|p=vii}} ''Kural'' means something that is "short, concise, and abridged."{{sfn|Sundaram, 1990|pp=7–16}} Etymologically, ''kural'' is the shortened form of ''kural paattu'', which is derived from ''kuruvenpaattu'', one of the two Tamil poetic forms explained by [[Tolkappiyam]], the other one being ''neduvenpaattu''.{{sfn|Kowmareeshwari, 2012a|pp=iv–vi}} According to Winslow, ''kural'' is used as a literary term to indicate "a metrical line of 2 feet, or a distich or couplet of short lines, the first of 4 and the second of 3 feet." Thus, ''Tirukkural'' literally comes to mean "sacred couplets."{{sfn|Sundaram, 1990|pp=7–16}} The Kural is unique among ancient works that it did not have a name nor did it have any mention of the author's name in it at the time of its release at the ruler's court at the city of [[Madurai]], the seat of the [[Third Sangam|Third Tamil Sangam]].{{sfn|Pope, 1886|p=i (Introduction)}} The author used the title ''Muppāl'', meaning "three divisions," to present it to the King,{{sfn|Pillai, 1972|p=3}} since the work was written about the first three of the four ancient Indian aims in life, known as ''[[Puruṣārtha|purushaarthas]]'', viz., virtue, wealth and love,{{sfn|Sundaram, 1990|pp=7–16}}{{sfn|Lal, 1992|pp=4333, 4341}} with the fourth aim, namely, salvation (''moksha''), implicitly said in the last five chapters of Book I.{{sfn|Pillai, 1972|pp=5–7}} Remaining nameless for several years after its writing, the work came to be referred to by various names in the centuries that followed. Nine traditional names had already been in use to refer to the book during the time of writing of the ''[[Tiruvalluva Maalai]]'', a eulogy written on the Kural by various poets between the 1st and 11th centuries CE.{{sfn|Zvelebil, 1973|pp=155–156}} Nevertheless, the title ''Muppāl'' remained the work's primary name until the 13th century CE.{{sfn|Aravindan, 1968|p=105}} It is estimated that the Kural has historically been known by as many as 44 names given at various periods over the millennia, making it one of the numerously titled works.{{sfn|Velusamy and Faraday, 2017|pp=54–55}} ==Organization of the work== The Kural is structured into 133 chapters, each containing 10 couplets (or kurals), for a total of 1,330 couplets.{{sfn|Kumar, 1999|pp=91–92}}{{Ref label|B|b|none}} The 133 chapters are grouped into three parts, or "books":{{sfn|Kumar, 1999|pp=91–92}}{{sfn|Mukherjee, 1999|pp=392–393}} * Book I – Aṟattuppāl (அறத்துப்பால்): [[Aram (Kural book)|Book of Virtue]] ([[Dharma]]), dealing with virtues independent of the surroundings (Chapters 1-38) * Book II – Poruṭpāl (பொருட்பால்): [[Porul (Kural book)|Book of Polity]] ([[Artha]]), dealing with virtues with respect to the surroundings (Chapters 39-108) * Book III – Kāmattuppāl (காமத்துப்பால்): [[Inbam (Kural book)|Book of Love]] ([[Kama]]), dealing with virtues involved in conjugal human love (Chapters 109-133) Each ''kural'' or couplet contains exactly seven words, known as ''cir''s, with four ''cir''s on the first line and three on the second, following the [[Kural (poetic form)|kural]] [[Poetic metre|metre]]. A ''cir'' is a single or a combination of more than one Tamil word. For example, the term ''Thirukkural'' is a ''cir'' formed by combining the two words ''thiru'' and ''kuṛaḷ''. The book on ''Aṟam'' (virtue) contains 380 verses, that of ''Poruḷ'' (wealth) has 700 and that of ''Inbam'' (love) has 250.{{sfn|Kumar, 1999|pp=91–92}} The overall organisation of the Kural text is based on seven ideals prescribed for a commoner besides observations of love.{{sfn|SSP, 2012|pp=vii–xvi}} This includes 40 couplets on God, rain, ascetics, and virtue; 200 on domestic virtue; 140 on higher yet most fundamental virtue based on grace, benevolence and compassion; 250 on royalty; 100 on ministers of state; 220 on essential requirements of administration; 130 on morality, both positive and negative; and 250 on human love and passion.{{sfn|Lal, 1992|pp=4333–4334}}{{sfn|SSP, 2012|pp=vii–xvi}} {{hidden begin |title = Outline of the Kural |titlestyle = background:lightgreen;width:60% }} ;Book I—Book of Virtue (38 chapters) * Chapter 1.
